Award.AwardTitle: Workshop/Collaborative Research: 2010 NSF Proposal Writing Workshop; September 1-2, 2010; University of Nebraska-Lincoln

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This collaborative award provides support for the conduct of a NSF proposal writing workshop to be held September 1-2, 2010, at the University of Nebraska-Lincoln, Lincoln, Nebraska. Provision is made for 150 attendees who will be selected from among the applicants giving priority to early career faculty in EPSCoR states, especially Arkansas, Kansas, Nebraska, Oklahoma, South Dakota and Wyoming, whose research will likely receive support from the Division of Civil, Mechanical and Manufacturing Innovation, and to members of underrepresented groups. The workshop will include a lecture on the basics of proposal writing, experiences of recent NSF awardees, and mock panel reviews of actual recent NSF proposals and of the attendees' own proposal summaries.

Previous similar workshops have attracted typically twice as many applicants as can be accommodated at the workshop. Previous attendees have enjoyed significantly higher proposal success rates with their proposals. Thus, it is expected that this workshop will provide information that will enable the attendees to write more competitive proposals and subsequently improve the quality of their research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
An NSF proposal writing workshop was held on September 1 and 2, 2010, at University of Nebraska-Lincoln. The workshop mainly aimed to provide future NSF proposal submitters with proposal review experience and interactions with NSF program directors and recent NSF awardees.

 

Intellectual Merit

Major activities of the workshop include: presentations by NSF program directors and recent NSF awardees; mock panel review sessions on both successful and unsuccessful NSF proposals; mock panel review sessions on project summaries of participants’ own NSF proposals; and interactions among workshop participants, NSF program directors, and recent NSF awardees. Such workshops were held every year since 2004. They were well attended and highly evaluated by workshop participants.

 

Broader Impacts

More than 100 junior professors across the nation participated in the workshop. The workshop provided them with opportunities to learn the guidelines of writing a good NSF proposal. This will positively affect these professors’ career as educators. This in turn will help develop the human resources of the nation.

 

The event was targeted at EPSCoR states, especially Arkansas, Kansas, Iowa, Nebraska, Oklahoma, South Dakota, and Wyoming. The location of the workshop (Lincoln, Nebraska) was within half-day driving distance from these EPSCoR states. The workshop was also open to participants from non-EPSCoR states.
